abstract: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. News of Mr. Scott-Barrett’s departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain. ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America. That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.
